title-group.article-title: Handling ability of gaseous microemboli of two pediatric arterial filters in a simulated CPB model

contrib-group.aff: 1Huron High School, Ann Arbor Public Schools, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
2Department of Pediatrics, Penn State Hershey Pediatric Cardiovascular Research Center, Hershey, PA, USA
3Public Health and Sciences, Hershey, PA, USA
4Surgery, and Bioengineering, Penn State Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Penn State Hershey College of Medicine, Penn State Hershey Children’s Hospital, Hershey, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Akif Ündar Professor of Pediatrics, Surgery, and Bioengineering Penn State Hershey College of Medicine, Department of Pediatrics – H085 500 University Drive P.O. Box 850 Hershey PA 17033-0850 USA Email: aundar@psu.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The purpose of this experiment was to compare the Sorin KIDS D131 and the Terumo Capiox AF02 pediatric arterial filters in a simulated CPB procedure to determine which filter is the better for clinical use.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The experimental circuit was primed with an 800 ml combination of lactated Ringer’s solution and human blood (hematocrit (Hct) 30%). The two filters were tested under flow rates of 500, 1000, and 1500 ml/min at room temperature and their purge lines opened and closed as 5cc of air was injected into the circuit.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: As the flow rates increased, the number of gaseous microemboli (GME) being returned to the pseudo patient increased for both of the pediatric arterial filters. Having an open purge line increased the number of GME removed from the CPB circuit, caused less of a pressure drop than when closed and increased the total hemodynamic energy loss than when closed. Both of the filters performed and reacted similarly in decreasing GME, hemodynamic energy loss and pressure drop. The only minor difference was that the Capiox AF02 had slightly less stolen blood flow (109.5 ± 1.7 ml/min at 500 ml/min, 114.7 ± 1.1 ml/min at 1000 ml/min and 105.8 ± 4.2 ml/min at 1500ml/min) from the open purge line than the KIDS D131 (119.5 ± 2.5 ml/min at 500 ml/min, 128.3 ± 1.0 ml/min at 1000 ml/min and 126.3 ± 3.1 ml/min at 1500 ml/min).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Our study confirmed that both the Sorin KIDS D131 and the Terumo Capiox AF02 were equivalent in their ability to remove significant numbers of GME, the amount of pressure drop and the total hemodynamic energy loss across the arterial filters at the various flow rates. An arterial filter is not an option, but a necessity for removing microemboli delivered to the patient.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the United States of America, approximately 8 per 1,000 live births have congenital heart defects; an estimated minimum of 32,000 infants are expected to be affected each year.1 Approximately 20,000 open-heart surgeries are performed in children each year. The majority of pediatric patients with congenital heart disease are in need of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). During the CPB procedure, the patient’s blood comes in contact with artificial surfaces, air and operating site particles, such as fat, activated platelets, tissue and fibers. These patients are at risk for postoperative neurological injury and organ dysfunction due to particulates and gaseous emboli.2,3 These gaseous microemboli (GME) and particles must be removed from a patient’s blood- stream before the blood is delivered to the patient. Otherwise, GME and particles can become lodged in small vessels, resulting in the dysfunction of organs due to microembolisms.2,4 –7

In order to minimize the risk of foreign objects and GME from entering a patient’s bloodstream, many filters are used in an attempt to trap the particles and GME before they can reach the patient. These filters include: a pre-bypass filter, a cardioplegia filter, a venous reservoir filter, a cardiotomy reservoir filter with de-foaming material, an arterial filter and some specially-designed filters, for example, a leukocyte-depletion filter, a blood transfusion filter and an aortic filter.4,5,8,9 Of these, arterial filters are playing a crucial role in capturing arterial GME in the CPB circuit. In the United States, most pediatric CPB procedures are now done with the use of an arterial filter. However, several centers do not use the arterial filter in order to reduce the priming volume of the circuit.9 We have already documented that the arterial filter is not an option, but a necessity for removing microemboli delivery to the patient.11 –15 In addition, hollow-fiber membrane oxygenators can trap the majority of GME in the CPB circuit; novel hollow-fiber membrane oxygenators with integrated arterial filters not only reduce the priming volume, but also capture most of the GME.12,13,16,17

Any component in the CPB circuit should be tested in vitro and in vivo before it is used in clinical practice. The present study was to compare the Sorin KIDS D131 and the Terumo Capiox AF02 pediatric arterial filters’ ability to filter out GME and the filters’ overall proficiency, using human blood during a simulated pediatric CPB procedure. This will help us decide which pediatric arterial filter is better for clinical use.

sec.title: Experimental circuit design
sec.p: The experimental circuit was created to perform an in vitro CPB procedure (Figure 1). The circuit was composed of a hard-shell venous/cardiotomy reservoir (Terumo Corporation, Tokyo, Japan), a Jostra HL-20 roller pump (Maquet, Hirrlingen, Germany), two arterial filters - the Terumo Capiox AF02 pediatric arterial filter and the Sorin KIDS D131 pediatric arterial filter (Sorin Group USA, Inc. Arvada, CO) (details about the filters in Table 1) and two identical purge lines extending from each of the arterial filters to a cardiotomy reservoir. The purge line was composed of 24 in (1/8 x 1/32) tubing without a one-way valve, a COBE 5-port manifold and 48 in (3/32 x 1/16) tubing.

The circuit was primed with 800 ml of room temperature, lactated Ringer’s solution and de-aired to clinical standards. Heparinized human blood was then added to the circuit (Hct of 30 %). A Hoffman clamp was utilized on the venous line to maintain a blood level of 200 ml in the venous reservoir and 300 ml in the pseudo patient. A second Hoffman clamp was placed at the distal end of the arterial line to maintain a pre-cannula pressure of 100 mmHg.

sec.title: Emboli detection and classification
sec.p: With the invention of the Emboli Detection and Classification (EDAC) Quantifier (Luna Innovations Inc., Roanoke, VA), GME as small as 10 microns can be detected. The EDAC Quantifier uses sonar to detect GME from up to three locations simultaneously. It can count up to 1000 GME per second, classify them by size and can do it all with flow rates ranging from 0.2-6.0 L/min. The EDAC Quantifier has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for clinical use. In Penn State Hershey Children’s Hospital, the EDAC system has been used in pediatric cardiac CPB procedures.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: In order to use the EDAC Quantifier, three connecters were inserted into the circuit. One each post venous reservoir, prearterial filter and post arterial filter. The three corresponding transducer clamps were then attached. Also attached to the circuit were two pressure transducers and two flow probes that were attached pre and post arterial filter. In addition, the two arterial filters were attached to a pressure monitor. (Figure 1) The pressure transducer and flow meter outputs were linked to a custom-made data acquisition device (NI USB-6251, National Instruments, Austin, TX) and then connected to a computer. A LabView 7.1 (National Instruments, Austin, TX) custom interface was then used to collect data.

The trials were conducted at flow rates of 500, 1000, and 1500 ml/min, under non-pulsatile perfusion mode and at room temperature. During the trials, either the Terumo Capiox AF02 arterial filter was used with an open or closed purge line or the Sorin KIDS D131 arterial filter with an open or closed purge line. The Terumo Capiox Baby RX05 Oxygenator was bypassed in order to obtain data focused on the arterial filters. During the trials, 5cc of air was injected into the venous line during a 15 second interval before the GME count returned to baseline. The duration of each trial lasted two minutes as each transducer collected its data at each experimental condition. Six trials were run for each of the two arterial filters: three flow rates and two purge line statuses (open and closed), which yielded 72 total trials.

sec.title: Hemodynamic energy calculations
sec.p: With the help of the Shepard’s energy equivalent pressure (EEP) formula and simultaneous blood flow (f) and pressure (p) recorded by the Labview software, EEP, surplus hemodynamic energy (SHE) and total hemodynamic energy (THE) were calculated in a time interval (t1 and t2) as follows.18
SHE (ergs/cm3) = 1,332 * (EEP - mean pressure)
THE (ergs/cm3) = 1,332 * EEP
The constant 1,332 converts pressure from units of mmHg to dynes per cm2 (1 mmHg = 1332 dyn/cm2).

sec.title: Statistical methods
sec.p: An analysis of variance (ANOVA) model was fit to each continuous outcome (e.g., pressure drop) to compare filters (i.e., Terumo Capiox AF02, Sorin KIDS D131), purge line status (open, closed) and flow rates. For each outcome, p-values were adjusted for multiple comparisons testing, using the Tukey-Kramer procedure. All hypotheses tests were two-sided and all analyses were performed using version 9.3 of the SAS System for Windows (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC).

sec.title: GME total counts and total volumes
sec.p: Regardless of which of the two arterial filters was used, an increase of the flow rate from 500 ml/min to 1500 ml/min (at 500 ml/min intervals) elevated the number of GME present in the circuit when 5 cc of air was injected from the venous line. These GME were detected by the EDAC quantifier to be in greatest quantity post venous reservoir and in least abundance post arterial filter. At flow rates of 1000 ml/min and 1500 ml/min, the Capiox AF02 filters captured slightly more GME from pre to post arterial filter than the KIDS D131. At a flow rate of 500 ml/min, the standard deviations are high and the results may be biased. (Table 2)

caption.p: Total emboli counts and total emboli volume (ml) at the inlet and outlet of the Terumo and Sorin pediatric arterial filters at different flow rates.

fn.p: P<0.01, the arterial filter purge line: Closed vs. Open

sec.title: GME sizes
sec.p: At a flow rate of 500ml/min, no microemboli larger than 40 microns were detected pre or post the arterial filter. As the flow rated increased from 1000 ml/min to 1500 ml/min, GME larger than 40 microns were discovered, as well as a dramatic increase of GME in the size categories of 10-20 microns and 20-40 microns.( Table 3) There was no significant difference between the two filters.

caption.p: Different sized gaseous microemboli at the inlet and outlet of the Terumo and Sorin pediatric arterial filters at different flow rates.

fn.p: P<0.01, the arterial filter purge line: Closed vs. Open.

sec.title: Pressure drop, energy lost and “stolen” blood flow
sec.p: An increase in flow rate also caused a pressure drop and increased total of hemodynamic energy lost across the filters. At a 500 ml/min flow rate, the pressure drop was 15.1-17.5 mmHg, at 1000 ml/min 22.2-24.7 mmHg and at 1500 ml/min a pressure drop of 34.4-38.0 mmHg. One thing that did remain consistent as the flow rate increased was the stolen blood flow amount from the open purge line. At all three flow rates, the KIDS D131’s stolen blood flow (119.5 ± 2.5 ml/min at 500 ml/min, 128.3 ± 1.0 ml/min at 1000 ml/min and 126.3 ± 3.1 ml/min at 1500 ml/min) was larger than the Capiox AF02’s stolen blood flow (109.5 ± 1.7 ml/min at 500 ml/min, 114.7 ± 1.1 ml/min at 1000 ml/min and 105.8 ± 4.2 ml/min at 1500ml/min).( Figure 2)

caption.p: The stolen blood flow from the open arterial filter purge line.
* P<0.01 KIDS D131 vs. Capiox AF02.
# P<0.01 Flow rates compared to 500 ml/min.

sec.title: Purge line mode
sec.p: At all flow rates and for both the D131 and AF02, the percentage of GME removed when the purge line was open was always greater than when the purge-line was closed (Table 2). Having the purge line open also decreased the pressure drop across both of the arterial filters and increased the total hemodynamic energy loss across the arterial filters when compared to the same experiment with the purge line closed. This is shown in Figure 3 and Figure 4, respectively.

caption.p: The pressure drop across the arterial filters.
* P<0.01 Arterial filter purge line: Closed vs. Open.
# P<0.01 Flow rates compared to 500 ml/min.
Total hemodynamic energy loss across the arterial filters.
P<0.01 Flow rates compared to 500 ml/min.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The source of microemboli in CPB circuits can be multifactorial, including residual air in the venous cannula, a non-occlusive atrial purse-string, vent and suction lines, the use of vacuum-assisted venous drainage or their introduction during blood sampling, drug injection, removal of the aortic cross-clamp, after aortic cannulation and on initiation of CPB.7,19 –23 Gaseous emboli that are entrained in the CPB procedure are associated with neurological morbidity, particularly in children.24 They are at an increased risk for complications after cardiac surgery, such as growth problems and learning difficulties.25 That is why it is imperative to have various filters in the circuit, to remove particulates and gaseous emboli and to make CPB safer. The arterial filter is the last security filter in the CPB circuit that the blood passes through before entering the patient. Therefore, it is necessary to do translational research for selecting the best arterial filter in order to minimize the risk of embolic neurologic events.

In the present study, although the filter screen area of the Sorin KIDS D131 filter was smaller and the pore size was larger than the Terumo Capiox AF02, both pediatric arterial filters were almost equal in their ability to capture and remove GME from the extracorporeal circuit. This means that the smaller pore size (Capiox AF02, 32μm vs. KIDS D131, 40μm) and the larger filter surface area (Capiox AF02, pleated screen vs. KIDS D131, tiled screen) are not the only factors that make a better arterial filter. Consideration of other factors, such as the hydro-mechanical structure, size and coating technique of the filters removing GME, should be taken into account. The pressure drop was comparable in both of the arterial filters as the flow rate increased. The pressure drop over the arterial filters was greater when the purge line was closed than when it was open. Regardless of having an open or closed purge line, the pressure loss across the filters was higher than expected. This may be because of distant pressure monitoring sites to the arterial filters. The pressure drops across the two filters were comparable. A lower pressure drop could result in a decreased amount of trauma inflicted on the blood cells and a better chance of filtering out GME. At the same time, the Terumo Capiox AF02 and Sorin KIDS D131 had similar total hemodynamic energy loss across the filters. The total hemodynamic energy loss is a culmination of pressure drop and stolen blood flow. At each of the three flow rates, the energy lost was slightly greater, for both filters, when the purge line was open.

The CPB circuit pressure drop not only depends on the oxygenator pressure drop, but also the arterial filter pressure drop and tubing pressure drop. In our previous study, we measured the oxygenator pressure drops of different pediatric oxygenators.12–14 Figure 5 presents the oxygenator pressure drop (data from our previous study12) plus the arterial filter pressure drop (data from the present study) if the same brand of oxygenator and arterial filter are used. When both of the oxygenator and separated arterial filter pressure drops were considered, the circuit pressure drop significantly increased. Higher circuit pressure may result in hemolysis, damage to platelets and systemic inflammatory response. The oxygenator with the integrated arterial filter, in terms of circuit pressure drop, has a great advantage over the others. Nevertheless, overall performance of a hollow-fiber membrane oxygenator should be considered, including pressure drop, bubble-handling ability, oxygenation and heat exchange efficiencies.

caption.p: Oxygenator and separated arterial filter vs. oxygenator with integrated arterial filter pressure drops.

sec.p: At all three flow rates, the Terumo Capiox AF02 had a slightly less amount of stolen blood flow than the Sorin KIDS D131. Although they were both tested at different flow rates, their individual stolen blood flow amounts remained the same. The consistent results were due to the maintained pre-cannula pressure of 100 mmHg. Our previous study confirmed that stolen blood flow is dependent on the circuit pressure, not the flow rate.26 Since the open purge line diverts or “steals” some of the oxygenated blood from the patient, the patient might not receive the amount of oxygenated blood needed. So, a flow probe (distal to the arterial filter) was recommended to be used to monitor real-time arterial flow in the setting of an open arterial filter purge line, especially at low flow rates.

Arterial filters are mostly used during pediatric CPB in the United States, but not as often as used in some heart centers in Europe. One reason arterial filters are not used in pediatrics is so that the priming volume is decreased and, therefore, hemodilution of the blood is not so great. The novel hollow-fiber membrane oxygenator with integrated arterial filter may gain two advantages – capturing GME and reducing the priming volume for pediatric CPB procedures. Our in vitro experiments showed that these hollow-fiber membrane oxygenators with integrated arterial filters could capture a majority of arterial GME, but they were not as good as separate arterial filters.11,12 Despite the controversy which exists about the use of arterial filters,27 we have clearly documented that the benefits are far more important for the safety of the patients compared to the related risks, including increased priming volume, diverted blood flow via the purge line, etc.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our results showed that both the Sorin KIDS D131 and the Terumo Capiox AF02 Pediatric arterial filters were equally effective at removing GME in a simulated CPB circuit. The two filters had similar amounts of pressure drop and total hemodynamic energy loss across the arterial filters at the various flow rates. One difference was the Terumo Capiox AF02 arterial filter had a lower stolen blood flow from the open purge line when compared to the Sorin KIDS 131. This experiment was a simulated procedure, in vitro and not in vivo. The next step for this experiment would be to conduct an in vivo set of trials. Based on these results, an arterial filter is not an option, but a necessity for removing microemboli delivery to the patient.
